questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is false regarding demyelinating disorders?

options.c: Multiple sclerosis is the most common type
options.d: It is caused by biochemical abnormality of myelin

questions.explanation:
Demyelinating disorders do not include biochemical abnormalities of myelin. Disorders occuring 
due to biochemical abnormalities of myelin are called dysmyelinating disorders. Multiple sclerosis is the most common immune-mediated, inflammatory demyelinating disorder. 
It commonly presents in adulthood.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is true regarding multiple sclerosis?

options.a: It is an acute inflammatory condition of neurons
options.b: It is an autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system
options.c: It may also involve the peripheral nervous system
options.d: The condition is always benign and resolves spontaneously

questions.explanation:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system. It is characterized by 
chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss. The peripheral nervous system is spared in MS. The course of the disease may be relapsing-remitting or progressive. The clinical course of 
manifestation can be variable ranging from a benign condition to a rapidly evolving and 
incapacitating disease. 1188 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient with weakness of the limbs and reduced vision, after evaluation, was diagnosed to 
be a case of multiple sclerosis. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development 
of this condition?
questions.explanation: HLA-DRB1 is a risk factor for the development of multiple sclerosis, not HLA-B27. Risk factors supporting the course of development of multiple sclerosis include: • Cigarette smoking • Vitamin D deficiency • Family history, HLA-DRB1 • Exposure to Epstein-Barr virus (Human Herpesvirus 4) after early childhood

questions.question: Question 4: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
In multiple sclerosis, the slowing of conduction is due to the loss of the myelin sheath. Under normal circumstances, nerve conduction in myelinated axons occurs in a saltatory manner 
i.e from one node of Ranvier to another. But, when demyelination sets in, the nerve impulse are 
unable to travel as fast due to not being saltatory. This produces either a conduction block or 
delay. Lesions due to multiple sclerosis begin with perivenular cuffing by inflammatory mononuclear 
cells. Myelin-specific autoantibodies cause degeneration of myelin sheaths. As lesions evolve, 
prominent astrocytic proliferation (gliosis) is observed. Demyelination is the hallmark in the pathology of multiple sclerosis. But, it is not solely a disease 
affecting the myelin sheath. Partial or total axonal destruction (neuronal loss) can also occur.

questions.question: Question 5: Autoantibodies in multiple sclerosis are directed against which of the following?

options.b: Both Myelin basic protein & Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein

questions.explanation:
The autoantibodies in multiple sclerosis are directed against both myelin basic protein (MBP) and 
myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG).

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following processes lead to the formation of shadow plaques in patients with 
multiple sclerosis?

options.a: Demyelination of axons in the central nervous system
options.b: Demyelination of axons in the peripheral nervous system
options.c: Remyelination of axons in the central nervous system
options.d: Remyelination of axons in the peripheral nervous system

questions.explanation:
Remyelination of axons in the central nervous system leads to the formation of shadow plaques. Shadow plaques develop due to the partial remyelination of the naked axons by surviving 
oligodendrocytes or those that differentiate from precursor cells.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 40-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis comes to the hospital. She describes 
an electric shock–like sensation radiating down the back into the legs. What is the name of 
this sign?
questions.explanation:
1189 
Sold by @itachibot An electric shock-like sensation radiating down the back into the legs is called Lhermitte's sign. It 
is associated with multiple sclerosis. It is induced typically by flexion or other movements of the neck. Lhermitte’s sign can also occur 
simultaneously with other disorders of the cervical spinal cord like cervical spondylosis. Option A: Uhthoff ’s phenomenon refers to the unilateral visual blurring that may occur during a 
hot shower or with physical exercise. It is an exacerbation of the symptoms of multiple sclerosis 
due to heat. Option C: Stransky's sign is a clinical sign in which vigorous abduction followed by the sudden 
release of the little toe causes an extensor plantar reflex. It is seen in pyramidal tract lesions. Option D: Cornell's sign is a clinical sign in which scratching along the inner side of the extensor 
hallucis longus tendon elicits an extensor plantar reflex. It is seen in pyramidal tract lesions.

questions.question:
Question 8: An MRI image of a patient with multiple sclerosis is shown below. What is this sign called? 1184 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The MRI image shows Dawson's fingers. Dawson's fingers are demyelinating plaques through the corpus callosum, arranged at right angles 
along medullary veins (callososeptal location). They are a characteristic feature of multiple 
sclerosis and presents as T2 hyperintensities. MRI is the imaging of choice in a patient with multiple sclerosis due to its high sensitivity. Option A: Black hole lesions are multiple sclerosis plaques indicative of the chronic stage when 
they display T1 hypointense signals. They signify axonal destruction and irreversible damage. Option B: The molar tooth sign refers to the appearance of the midbrain in an axial section in 
which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles gives the midbrain the appearance of a molar 
or wisdom tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome. Option C: Tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex in patients 
with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 9: A woman presents with recurrent episodes of blurry vision, tingling and numbness in the 
legs, and falls. She says that during hot weather, she finds it difficult to walk and often falls. 
Recently she had flu, due to which the symptoms aggravated. MRI brain was done which 
showed Dawson's fingers. What is the criteria used for the clinical diagnosis of her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and the MRI finding of Dawson's fingers are suggestive of multiple sclerosis. 
Revised McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. It takes into 
consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves the assessment 
of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques. The Kurtzke expanded disability status scale (EDSS) and functional status (FS) score are widely 
used measures of neurologic impairment, which are performed following the confirmed diagnosis 
of multiple sclerosis.

questions.question:
Question 10: In patients with multiple sclerosis, which of the following is used to determine neurological 
impairment?
questions.explanation:
1190 
Sold by @itachibot The Expanded disability status scale (EDSS) gives a measure of neurological impairment in 
multiple sclerosis. EDSS scores <3.5: The patient walks normally, shows no disability EDSS scores >5.5: Progressive disease, gait impairment, and occupational disability EDSS scores =10.0: Death due to multiple sclerosis

questions.question:
Question 11: A 45-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis presents with an exacerbation of her symptoms. 
Which of the following drugs should be prescribed to her for initial management?
questions.explanation:
Glucocorticoids are used in the clinical management of either first attacks or acute exacerbations. Intravenous methylprednisolone administration at a dose of 500–1000 mg/day for 3-5 days, 
followed by a course of oral prednisolone beginning at a dose of 60–80 mg/day and gradually 
tapered over 2 weeks is given. These medications reduce the severity and shorten the duration of attacks. Disease-modifying therapies for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis are: • IFN--1a • IFN--1b • Glatiramer acetate • Natalizumab • Fingolimod • Dimethyl fumarate • Teriflunomide • Mitoxantrone • Alemtuzumab

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following patients have Marburg’s variant of multiple sclerosis?

options.a: A patient with chronic form of multiple sclerosis with no remissions
options.b: A patient with acute form of multiple sclerosis with remissions
options.c: A patient with acute form of multiple sclerosis with no remissions
options.d: A patient with chronic form of multiple sclerosis with remissions

questions.explanation:
Marburg’s variant is an acute form of multiple sclerosis, typically with no remissions. It is a fulminant demyelinating process that in some cases progresses, leading to death within 1–2 
years. Marburg’s variant does not seem to be associated with infection or vaccination. Clinical management by high-dose glucocorticoids, plasma exchange, and cyclophosphamide have 
been tried, with uncertain benefit.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual 
acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a 
partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of neuromyelitis optica, which is also known as Devic's disease. 1191 
Sold by @itachibot It is an aggressive inflammatory demyelinating disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of 
optic neuritis and myelitis. Attacks of Optic neuritis can be bilateral or unilateral and myelitis can 
be severe and involve three or more contiguous vertebral segments. Core clinical characteristics are: • Optic neuritis • Acute myelitis • Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting • Acute brainstem syndrome • Symptomatic narcolepsy or acute diencephalic clinical syndrome with NMOSD*-typical 
diencephalic MRI lesions • Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD*-typical brain lesions Option A: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is a demyelinating condition most 
frequently associated with an antecedent infection Option C: Riddoch syndrome is the ability to consciously perceive the stimulus in a blind field. It 
is seen when there is a lesion in the occipital lobe. Option D: Acute fulminant multiple sclerosis is an acute episode of multiple sclerosis, known as 
Marburg’s variant *NMOSD stands for neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for a patient with an acute attack of 
neuromyelitis optica?
questions.explanation:
Acute attacks of neuromyelitis optica are managed by high-dose glucocorticoids or plasma 
exchange. Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses include: • Mycophenolate mofetil • Rituximab • Glucocorticoids + azathioprine

questions.question:
Question 15: A child presents to the casualty with high-grade fever and altered sensorium. He is suspected 
to have acute disseminated encephalomyelitis. This condition is associated with which of the 
following?
questions.explanation:
Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is associated with measles infection, measles 
vaccination, rubella infection, and rubella vaccination. ADEM is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that typically presents as 
a monophasic disorder associated with multifocal neurological symptoms and encephalopathy. It 
may be : • Post-infectious (95%) - associated infections are with varicella, measles, rubella, mumps, 
influenza, EBV, HHV-6, HIV, other viruses, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae. 1192 
Sold by @itachibot • Post-vaccination (5%) - presently it is most often associated with measles (most common), 
mumps, and rubella vaccination.

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding acute disseminated 
encephalomyelitis?

options.a: Cerebellar involvement is seen in post-varicella ADEM
options.b: Autoantibodies to myelin basic protein can be found
options.d: Initial treatment is with high-dose glucocorticoids.

questions.explanation:
Seizures are common in ADEM. ADEM results from a cross-reactive immune response to the infectious agent (most commonly 
measles virus) or vaccine which then triggers an inflammatory demyelinating response. Autoantibodies to MBP and to other myelin antigens have been detected in the CSF of some 
patients with ADEM. In ADEM due to chickenpox, cerebellar involvement is often conspicuous. Initial treatment is with high-dose glucocorticoids.

questions.question: Question 17: Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in which of the following conditions?

options.c: A 38-year-old man presenting with a tight band-like discomfort around the head
options.d: A 34-year-old woman presenting with a pulsatile headache associated with nausea

questions.explanation:
Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease. It is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder characterized by central nervous system dysmyelination. The proteolipid protein gene (PLP1) is affected, leading to the failure of axon myelination by 
oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system. Clinical Features: • Nystagmus • Developmental delay • Psychomotor delay • Seizure • Stridor • Feeding difficulties • Ataxia • Hypotonia progressing to spasticity. The degree of dysmyelination is correlated with the severity of the clinical manifestations. Genetic analysis can confirm the diagnosis. MRI shows a lack of myelination and MR 
spectroscopy reveals aberrant N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) and choline concentrations that reflect 
axonal and myelination abnormalities. Unlike other demyelinating leukodystrophies such as metachromatic leukodystrophy and 
adrenoleukodystrophy, where myelin is formed but subsequently destroyed, PMD shows a failure 
of myelin formation. 1193 
Sold by @itachibot Headache Disorders
